The following is based on an NRICH puzzle
 https://nrich.maths.org/

Pegs numbered 1 to 50 are placed in order in a line, with number 1 on the left.
They are then knocked over, one at a time, following these two rules:

1. Starting with the first standing peg on the left, alternate pegs are knocked down, until the end of the row is reached.
2. Each time the end of the row is reached, repeat the previous rule.

What is the number of the last peg to be knocked down?
@results.s_ans is not correct.

Pegs numbered 1 to 10000050 are placed in order in a line, with number 1 on the left.
They are then knocked over, one at a time, following these two rules:

1. Starting with the first standing peg on the left, 9 pegs are knocked down and the tenth is left standing, until the end of the row is reached.
2. Each time the end of the row is reached, repeat the previous rule.

What is the number of the last peg to be knocked down?
Well done! That is absolutely right.

Hi All I am your friendly MathsBot demo. I can give you fun facts, puzzles and games. What do you want?

actions.text: Sorry, I'm really not that smart yet.
SHISIMA

SET UP:
1. Create the game board: draw an octagon and connect each corner to its opposite. The four lines intersect at the middle of the octagon forming the central point called shisima. Each of the eight corners of the octagon is also called a point. 

2. Give each player 3 pieces (called imbalavali) of different colour/design.

START:
Place the pieces on three consecutive points of the octagon, across from each other. There must be a vacant point on both ends of each player's set of pieces. This leaves three vacant points at the beginning of the game including the central point of the board.

RULES:
Players take turns moving their bugs one space along a marked line. A move must be to an adjacent corner, or to the center (shisima). Jumping pieces is not allowed, and there cannot be two pieces on the same point.

WINNER:
To win the game, a player must get three of their pieces in a row, including one piece on the shisima. (Therefore, there are four possible ways to win the game!).
Are you ready to play?

actions.text: Sorry, I'm really not that smart yet.

This game was originally played by Tiriki people in Kenya. The name Shisima means "body of water" and the pieces are called imbalavali which translates to "water bugs" as the pieces move quickly on the board as bugs do on the water surface.

goes to related activity
*in development*

The probability that two people have the same birthday is just 1 minus the probability of everyone's birthday being different.
If we only have 2 people what is the probability their birthday is different? 
If we had 5 people, in how many ways can we select two to compare their birthdays?

Have you experienced a surprising coincidence in your life? 
Coincidences like meeting someone with exactly the same birthday as you are unlikely events on their own. However, as with the birthday problem, the number of events can increase exponentially meaning that in a group or over time it is more likely to have coincidences than not!
If you haven’t had a coincidence yet don’t worry if you keep looking it’s unlikely that nothing unlikely will ever happen to you!

Sorry, I'm really not that smart yet.

The probability of any 2 people having different birthdays is roughly 364/365 there are 253 different pairs of people in a room of 23 people so the probability of them all having different birthdays is roughly 364/365 to the power 253. This is 0.4995 slightly less than 50% so the probability of having 2 people in the room with the same birthday is just over 50%. Actually we should be including leap years but the result is still true if you do.

actions.text:
There is a formula for adding the numbers 1,2,3,...n together. It is 1/2 n(n+1). For example 1+2+3+4+5+6+7=28 can be found by 1/2 x 7 x 8 = 28. 
The infinite series 1 + 2 +3 + 4 + ... diverges, but in some branches of maths it makes sense to say that if you keep adding the natural numbers 1 + 2 +3 + 4 + ... forever it would be equal to -1/12.

actions.text: Extension 2 - Hint
Sorry, I'm really not that smart yet.
Patience

This is a one player game of Patience. Lay out a grid of 8 cards in 2 rows of 4 cards, face up. Use the remaining cards to cover pairs of cards that sum to 11 (not including picture cards) and to cover sets of 3 picture cards, a Jack, Queen and King, which do not have to be the same suit. The object of the game is to put down all the cards in your hand.

actions.text: This game is mostly luck - but you need to think carefully about how many Jacks, Queens and Kings you cover to win the final stage!

Ace has a value of 1 in this game. If you manage to play all your cards, the last stage of the game is to pick up pairs of whole piles of cards whose top cards add up to 11, or three piles whose top cards are J, Q, K. You have won the game if you can pick up all the cards.

actions.text: These types of games are often called Patience or Solitaire. Patience because you need a lot of patience to try and win, and Solitaire because you can play them on your own. Although many variations of Patience are down to chance, it is interesting to use mathematics to analyse the probability of winning.
